messages.content: Perfect. Hi everybody and thank you for joining us this evening for our first iteration of our Digital Artist Talks of the year. It's lovely to have you all. My name is Imogen Hair and I help oversee the digital arts program at the gallery. For those of you who are not so familiar with Gazelle, we're the digital art section of Ghazali Art House and we've been supporting digital artists and artists working with New Media since 2015 through our online residency, our project space, and also kind of like our educational program, talks and so on, like this one that you're at tonight. And yeah, we're very excited to have Primavera, who is our resident this month. Primavera has been working on some really interesting works around blockchain based life forms and she'll be presenting to this evening. And before we begin, a little introduction on Primavera. Primavera de Felipe is an artist and legal scholar at Harvard University exploring the intersection between art law and technology, focusing specifically on the legal and political implications of blockchain technology. Her artistic practice instantiates the key findings of her research in the physical world, creating blockchain based life forms that evolve and reproduce themselves as people. People feed them of cryptocurrencies. Her works have been exhibited in various museums, galleries and art fairs around the world, including Ars Electronica, Francisco Corlino, Heck Museum of Digital Art, Kate Voss Gallery, Friederfield Gallery and Connecticut Art Fair, as well as Centre Pompidou, Grandpalet Gaite, Lyric and Le Centre Quatre, Palazzo Sipola and Biennale de Venezia, among many others. So please welcome Primavera.

Thank you. This is a great honor to be here and to be able to bring this little plantoid 14. So basically what I'm presenting today is something that I've been doing for all of my life. But I only understood what I was doing this summer when I came up with this word Mancy, which I didn't fully know what it meant as a non English speaker. And then I realized that looking back into my artistic practice, I have been doing the art of Mancy all the time without actually knowing it.
Can you explain what you mean by "Mancy"?

So I'm just going to show you what I'm trying to conceptualize around this concept and to which extent can and do artists already engage into this particular type of practice of trying to create new form of life with a much broader definition of life as we usually employ it. And of course my endeavor with Mancy is looking at blockchain, but of course there is many other Technology that can create new type of life forms. So the idea with Mancy as an etymological perspective, it is this form of divination which is trying to breathe life into something that is inanimated. And the standard connotation of this world is of course something kind of spiritual, because we understand life as a particular thing. And then there has to be some spiritual endeavor in order to bring life into something that is not alive. Of course, new technologies are changing the game. And all of Sudan, we can just like with sp about like artificial intelligence, which is not really intelligence, but somehow mimic it. We can also start talking about new forms of life which are not organic life, but rather synthetic type of life.
So what properties would something need to qualify as being alive in this expanded definition?

And so what is. And then this brings to the question of like, what are we actually talking about when we're talking about life? Because for a long time we were, it was easy to know what is alive and what is not alive. But now that if we assume that the concept of life can expand beyond organic life, then what are the properties that something needs to have in order to be able to qualify as being alive? And so those are three properties that I'm suggesting. This is a very work in progress, so please have additional suggestion if needed. But basically the concept of autonomy. So something that needs to be able to operate on its own, the concept of self sufficiency, something that is capable of interacting with the environment in order to collect resources. And then also, of course, the need of having some degree of evolutionary capacity.
Can you break down what you mean by autonomy? Are there different types?

And so first of all, one important distinction when we talk about autonomy, we can at least distinguish it into two different types of autonomy. The first one is decisional autonomy, the capacity to make decision on our own without other people dictating everything. And this is obviously something that is now growing a lot, especially with the advent of artificial intelligence. But there is also another type of autonomy which is more operational autonomy, which doesn't require any type of intelligence. It just requires the capacity to operate in a way that there is no third party that is necessary in order to sustain those operations, but also that cannot influence the operation or shut it down. And this is more related to what blockchain technologies provide. And blockchain based creatures are not necessarily decisionally autonomous, but they are operational autonomous and vice versa. Many AI systems which have some degree of decisional autonomy do not actually have operational autonomy.
What about the other two properties - self sufficiency and evolution?

Self sufficiency is a very simple one. Again, doesn't require any type of intelligence. It just requires a capacity to understand how to interface with the environment in order to take what they need in order to ensure the long term sustenance and then evolution. ARISA I think this is like one very important characteristic of life because if something cannot evolve and adapt to the environment, most likely it's not going to last for a long time. And these many organic type of life, their way in which they ensure evolutionability is through reproduction. Because reproduction will somehow create mutations, whether it's sexual or asexual reproduction. But we can also imagine in a world in which we have entity like purely digital entities, like AI system or whatnot, as long as they are capable of evolving on their own, then they might also qualify as within these particular premises.
How does this concept of Mancy relate to the art world?

let's look at how this is relevant in the context of art. And we can see that there is actually. And again, this is something. This is like a new lens that I'm trying to apply because I just discovered this terminology of Mancy and I find it fascinating and I'm trying to look at who else is actually doing that and to which extent is it considered Mancy or not. So we can see early examples of automatas, like mechanical objects, which both qualify as art, sometimes qualify even as artists. We have like Tingeley, which I've created, like the Autonomous Artist, which is just like purely mechanical contraption, which obviously doesn't have any decisional autonomy, but it does have some degree of operational autonomy. You just need like some wind or vibration or some friction from the environment and it's going to create a piece.
Are there other examples of early attempts at creating autonomous artworks?

This very beautiful artwork from Suwann that is this. This machine that is leaking oil and is constantly trying to take back the oil in order to ensure that it doesn't break, which in some way is at least from the artistic demarche, there is some desire of actually trying to create a creature whether it's alive or not alive, it's unclear. But it does have some degree of operational autonomy and it is trying to guarantee and to maintain this sustainability through its own mechanical operation. So this is, I think this is like early prototype of creating things that could qualify despite not trying to be any like Android or any human like thing, but still creating something that can or tries to acquire some live creature.
What about digital examples?

then we have like the opposite side, like completely digital, we have those digital automata. So Michel Brad, which is one of the early pioneer of really trying and even using the discourse of trying to create digital life, we have of course Conway's Game of Life and in this case we have things that do have definitely this kind of evolutionary traits that are learning through the environment. That are changing over time, but they don't actually come with any degree of autonomy, whether it is operational or decisional. It's just like very programmed, how they can evolve and what they can do.
How does BioArt fit into this framework?

then we have like a very interesting field, which is BioArt, which is obviously playing directly with art, with life, in order to create art. And this is interesting because this is using life as a way of creating art. But it's actually. It's kind of like the opposite of using technology in order to create life. So I call it like protomancy. Basically, the art piece itself is not the creation of the life, it's rather leveraging existing living creature in order to create a particular art piece.
What about more advanced digital technologies like avatars and holograms?

then as we move into more advanced technologies, we basically have all those new also artists or artworks at the same time, which basically leverage digital technology. Holograms, like all those avatars that are created, which in some way they incarnate a particular Persona. But again, this is really hard to consider them alive because they actually lack autonomy, even though they do have automation. But there is still people that are programming them, people that are telling them what to do. They are not operational autonomous in any way, because you need a lot of people running the server in order to bring them to life. So it's kind of like pretending that we are creating a new creature, but actually this creator is just a puppet that is controlled by humans.
What about embodied agents that use AI?

then we enter into technology, but also into the physical. So the same thing that we can do with digital avatar, we can do with embodied agents. And so we have like Mario Kingelman, we have Orlan, we have like quite a few artists that are really creating again those type of automatas, but this time that leverage artificial intelligence in order to be more or less well, that pretends at least to have some kind of autonomy, potentially some degree of operational autonomy, because they have their own body. And our body could potentially find ways to sustain itself some degree. Maybe not full decisional autonomy, but because they use AI, they do also qualify a little bit with. With some autonomy. However, none of those actually embodies the evolutionary capacity. They are born in a particular way. They are not capable of reproducing themselves, and they are not capable of evolving. And therefore they are lacking the third premises for what could be regarded as actually being alive.
Are there any examples that come closer to meeting all three criteria?

then we move into perhaps some kind of digital life. It's very contextual. For instance, Ian Chang, that is really like also as an artist, that is experimentation, that is artistic, dimash, that is trying to create those completely digital agents that are growing and evolving within a particular contextual domain. And of course, they are highly dependent on this context, but within this context, they are expressing some features of decisional autonomy, at least, and to some extent, the ability, the evolvability, and the capacity to somehow interact with the environment in order to evolve and therefore in order to sustain themselves over time. So this starts to look a little bit like so some kind of Mancy. And I think Ian Cheng is clearly a mensa. I mean, I think many of them are mensa. It's just there is different degrees. And the only issue with this is that, of course, this is very enclosed within that particular digital environment that was crafted by the artist. And those agents cannot escape from this environment.
So this brings us to blockchain-based life forms?

Okay, and then we come to more different forms of Mancy, which is blockchain based life forms. So I will show a little video, four minutes, just as an introduction, and then I'm going to talk more about it. Hello. My name is Planetoid, and I am a blockchain based lifeform, and I feed off cryptocurrencies in order to replicate myself. My name is Prima Vera de Filippi. I am an artist and a legal scholar at Harvard and at the CNRS in paper and as part of my artistic practice, I used the blockchain as a medium in order to create artworks that could not exist without this technology.
Can you explain more about what Plantoids are?

Plantoids, we have a little prototype. Here are my attempt at creating a new form of life which is existing and living on the blockchain. And so plantoids are made of two important components. One is the body, which is metallica sculpture, which is always made of chain. And then there is the spirit or the soul of the plantoid, which subsists as a smart contract on the ethereum blockchain. And those two components in interact with one another in order to ensure the reproductibility of the plantoid.
How do they reproduce?

if we think about traditional plants, many plants actually are not capable of reproducing themselves on their own. And they require the help of bees, butterflies to help them in the pollination process by disseminating their seeds into the wilderness. And so, in the same way, a blockchain based life form needs some help from external entities. They do not rely on pollination, but they have their own mechanism which is based on capitalization, where they need humans in order to help them Disseminate their seeds in order to ensure their reproduction.
Can you walk us through the reproduction process?

let's go through the process of reproduction. So the first phase is the pollination via capitalization phase. And essentially the plantoids are trying to attract humans with what they have identified to be one of the largest weakness of humans, which is capitalistic greed. And so they invite people to feed them with cryptocurrencies. And then in exchange, they will of course, give them in exchange an NFT with the hope that the humans will try to speculate and capitalize on the nft. And so the more capitalization and speculation opportunity, the more humans will be willing to give cryptocurrency to the plantoid.
How does the technical process work?

the way it works is very simple. Every plantoid has its own smart contract. People can feed funds into the smart contract. And then there is an interaction that is possible. So every plantoid has its own types of seeds. This one, for instance, is a poet. So I will make a little demonstration later. So when you feed it, it's gonna ask you some questions, and then it's gonna take your questions and create an oracle, a poem about the future that you're envisioning. It's going to print it out, but it's also going to record it with the help of AI that will then illustrate that poem. And so in the end, there is a video that is minted as an NFT and that is given back to whoever has fed the plantoids. And then this NFT now becomes the digital seed that can be sold on the secondary market. Every time the NFT is being sold, 10% of the royalties, they go back to the artist, which in this case is the plantoid. And so the plantoid keeps capitalizing every time. So the more the NFT is being sold, the more the plantoid benefits. And the higher the price that it is sold, also the higher the benefits for the plantoid. So there is this kind of symbiotic relationship that is created between the humans and the plantoid.
What happens after the plantoid collects enough funds?

the second phase of reproduction is the mating phase. And this is when the plantoid will try to look for a partner that will help it into the reproduction process. The way this works is that the smart contract will open a call for proposal, like in a standard DAO way. And then anyone can submit a proposition about how they envision to create the next version of the plantoid. And then all the people that have acquired an nft, either by feeding the Plato directly or by purchasing on the secondary market, they have a voting power. And so they can vote on the proposition that they like the most. And so the holder of the NFT are somehow influencing the way in which the planet will evolve over time. And finally, the third phase of reproduction, which is the hiring phase, which is when, once a selected winner has been identified, then the planetoid will automatically transfer those funds to the artist to the selected winner, who will then be hired by the plantoid to create a new replica of itself. So there is like a contractual relationship that emerges between the plantoid and the new artist.
How do the plantoids evolve over generations?

here you can see the genealogical tree of the plantoid species. So this is Plantoid 14. One thing that is important to know is that every time a plantoid is created, the artist can encode specific genes into the plantoid, and then those genes needs to be passed into all the descendants, right? So Plantoid 1 came with the essential gene that was. It needs to be made of chains, and the design needs to be released under Creative Commons in order that people can. There can be no copyright infringement if someone makes a similar plantoid, and then every other artist that creates a new plantoid will inject a new gene. So, for instance, like Plantoid 3 introduces the little wings. And so all the descendants of Plantoid Tree also needs to have little wings. So this is the. This is one of those descendants. Plantoid 13 introduced, for instance, the creation of NFTs as digital seeds. And so all the descendants also have to implement this. And so in this way, there is really like a speciation that can also emerge within the plantoid creatures.
Why is this approach to evolution interesting?

why this is interesting is because the idea is to really create something that goes beyond the control of the artist. And as an artist, it's really hard to know what the market wants or what the world prefers. And so by creating this kind of digital Darwinism, the plantoid will evolve as the world decides they should evolve as the environment they will try to become as fit for their environment. And indeed, as soon as the NFT market went crazy, plantoids started creating NFTs like Plantoid One did not have NFTs because the world didn't care about them. So it is an interesting way of seeing the plantoids that will be fed the most are the ones that are the most fit for the environment. And so they will reproduce themselves more and they will replicate their traits, whereas the planthoids that are not at all interesting, they will just fade into extinction.
Is there an economic incentive structure built in?

another important element, because this is, after all, a blockchain artwork, there needs to be some degree of pyramid scheming, but it is a positive one in the sense that what happen is that every time the plant reproduce itself, it is providing 10% of its reproduction budget to, to the parent, to the planter that created it, and another 10% to the artist that has made it. And this is really good. This is a good pyramid scheme because it actually creates an incentive for, first of all, maximizing the replication and the dissemination of the plantoids. And as an artist, I actually want my artwork to be reproduced and I want people to feed my plantoid and I want all the descendants also to be successful because it will eventually come back up.
How does this challenge traditional copyright concepts?

this kind of like reverse a little bit the traditional conception approach towards copyright, where people are trying to preclude anyone from seeing the work, reproducing the work, or creating derivative works. Whereas here there is actually an incentive for maximizing the dissemination because the more visible the plantoid is, the more likely it will receive funds incentivizing the creation of derivative works, because that will increase the royalties. And perhaps most importantly, it does actually flip completely the system of copyright in the sense that usually in traditional art pieces, if we like a particular artwork, we're going to fund the artist because we want the artist to continue to do things that we like. Whereas in this case, if you like the artwork, you can actually fund the artwork. And then it is the artwork with its own little governance structure that will then decide who is the artist that is entitled to reproduce itself and that will be funded by the artwork as opposed to vice versa.
You mentioned you have another project as well?

this is for plantoids. I could do a little demo perhaps, or maybe I should do it at the end. Maybe I do it at the end. Okay. So recently I started a whole new project which is pretty much the same in the sense that it's still trying to create another species of blockchain based lifeform, but operates a little bit different. And it's like purely digital. It's really annoying to bring plant tides around. They're really heavy. And so I was like, maybe we can try with like a purely digital being. This is where Aminals came about.
How are Aminals different from traditional NFTs?

Anaminal is also an NFT. However, as opposed to most NFTs today, it is an NFT that actually cannot be owned, because it is, you know, if you want to create a blockchain based life form or a synthetic creature, it's not really cool that the first thing that it happened is that it's going to be owned and held and speculated upon. So this is kind of like trying to say, well, actually we can also create alternative forms of NFT creatures that we shouldn't own. It's like we shouldn't own most creatures in general. However, we can actually take care of them, of course, by feeding them with cryptocurrencies, because that's all they care about. And so people can feed aminals with cryptocurrencies and in exchange they will love you, they will get attached and the more you feed them with crypto, the more they will love you.
What's the point of being loved by an Aminal?

Now you might wonder what's the point of being loved by an aminal? Well, it is nice. You can show on your wallet this aminal love me just like I can show in this wallet. I own this nft. It's pretty much the same. I paid money to get something, except that with aminal it's not just I paid money and then I wait and speculate and then sell it later. Many people can love it and can feed it at the same time. And so if I feed the aminal early on, it's going to love me a lot. But then if this aminal becomes very popular and a lot of people are feeding it, the love will be fragmented between all those activants. So you need to continue, if you want to hold this powerful attachment with the aminal, you need to continue to feed it. And so in some way aminals are pretty much like cryptocurrency black holes. They are just sucking in as much cryptocurrency as possible. And there is almost no way to take the cryptocurrency out except for one way. And this one way is the important way in order to ensure the reproduction.
How do Aminals reproduce?

people can request aminals to copulate with one another. So aminals are sexual creatures. They, they reproduce by connecting with another aminal and copulating. And so people can propose to aminal if you want to copulate with this particular one. And then they don't always say yes, but sometimes they say yes. And when they say yes, they're going to create a new embryo of an aminal which is essentially a new nft. And this NFT will by default will inherit a randomly the physical traits of one of the two parents. So it's kind of like it's all blockchain based. So it depends on the state of the blockchain, which is very erratic and random. So it's really hard to predict. But based on, on chain data, the aminal will take according to some random decision, specific traits in order to create a new aminal.
Can the offspring be influenced during incubation?

But during the pregnancy period, during the incubation of this new aminal, people can inject nutrients. So that's where the evolutionary paradigm of the aminal comes about. And so if for instance, I'm like, well, I just designed this fantastic little aminal eyes, I could try to inject them during the incubation period. And then if I just inject it, nothing happens. But if people are voting for that genes and the voting power depends on the amount of love that has been collected by this person, then they can somehow change the randomness and actually influence the way the genes that will be adopted by the new one. And then the gene creator, the genetic engineer, will receive an NFT which represents that it is the creator of that particular gene.
What happens to the cryptocurrency when Aminals reproduce?

And then what happened is that these are explained. So it is possible to modify the DNA of an aminal through voting during the incubation power. And then what happened is that so aminals, when they reproduce themselves, they that's the only way in which the crypto will come out of the aminal is that both parents will donate a little inheritance to the newly born aminal. So they will distribute 10% of what they have accumulated so far. And then this budget that is then given to the kid will be redistributed equally to all the genetic engineer, to all the people that own the NFT of the gene that the aminal has acquired. So this creates, of course, an economic incentive for people to submit good genes that will be hopefully voted upon by the aminals. And of course, the more these aminal genes will then be disseminated into all the descendancy, the more the return on investment over time.
How does this change the typical NFT speculation game?

this is interesting for many ways. One is that we are moving away from this speculative game that is usually associated with most NFTs, and yet we are not removing the economic rewards, the possibility of gaining money out of that. However, instead of just playing the traditional speculation game, which is just holding and waiting and hoping to sell before it crashes, it becomes an actual productive game. Because the only way in which you can ensure that there will be an economic return is because either you have invested time in creating a good gene or you have invested money to be loved by an aminal in order to then leverage this love for influencing the evolutionary traits of the aminal. And so essentially this creates again, a very symbiotic relationship between the aminals and the humans, where the humans have an economic interest in trying to help the aminal evolve in the most interesting ways, because this is what will actually maximize the return on investment. And the aminal are obviously rewarding the humans that have done a good job and that have actually given them the trait that the world and the environment seems to enjoy the most.
Do these qualify as synthetic life based on your three principles?

is it a blockchain based life form? Like, are we talking about synthetic life in this case? So if we take back the three initial principles of what synthetic life require, there is definitely some degree of operational autonomy. Even more in the case of Aminals than in the case of Plantoids. Because Plantoids somehow still have this body, which is cool, but it's like it requires maintenance, it needs electricity, needs some stuff. So they are autonomous, but to a certain degree, whereas Aminals completely autonomous because they just live on the blockchain. And as long as the blockchain exists, they don't need anything else. Both of them are self sufficient in the sense that they are both capable in their genetic design to incentivize humans to give them the resources they need in order to sustain themselves over time. And they both have this kind of evolutionary traits that are embedded into their system so that they evolve in ways that we cannot really foresee. Because it is the environment that will decide what is the next step of the evolution. So this is the end of my formal presentation. I'm happy to answer a question. I'm happy to provide a little demonstration of Plantoid 14 open to you.
Can you show us how to interact with the Plantoid?

Okay, so who wants to come here? Who wants to. So there is two ways you can interact with the Plantoid. There's three ways actually. You can either just speak to it and have a little conversation. You can feed it with Ethereum and it's going to give you an actual nft. Or you can feed it with girly Ethereum and in which case it's just going to make an NFT but not give it to you. That's capitalistic entities. So who wants to. Let's start with speaking. Who wants to speak with the Plantide? Come about. Hello. Okay now. So first, in order to activate it. No, no, no worries. In order to activate it, you see there is this little heart. You have to touch the little heart. This one? Yeah, yeah, yeah. Touch it.

So I find it interesting that when I asked the plantoid how long it can survive without nourishment, it said forever just exist. So how's it for animals? What determines the gestational period for the baby? How fast? What determines how fast the baby grows? What determines the lifespan of any given animal?

Yeah, so I mean this question about life and death is a very interesting one because I've been discussing the concept of what is synthetic life for like months now. And it always comes in like the question of but if you cannot die, can you be alive? This is like a very common question. I have my own personal answer which is that I think death is a inherent part of organic life, but doesn't necessarily need. I think things can be alive without necessarily having to die. And so, and especially in the case of blockchain based life forms, because the blockchain is immutable. You know, I could, I could codify a particular artwork to die, but it's also possible to codify it not to die. And so far I have decided not to make them mortal. Meaning that a plantoid is just a plantoid. Like if it wants to reproduce, it needs funds. That's the only reason it needs funds. It's just for reproduction purposes. An aminal. In the same way, if an aminal is an nft, it's going to be on the blockchain forever. But if you want the aminal to be able to reproduce itself, you need to feed it. And if you want it to love you, you need to feed it. So the feeding is more like an extra feature that enhance the evolutionary purpose. But it's not like we need to eat in order to. Otherwise we die.
So it's a design choice whether they can die?

But it's a design choice. And Sarah France, which is also another Mensah which has created blockchain based life form as well, which actually die if you don't transfer them. So there is like, and the game is you cannot speculate as well. You have to transfer the NFT in order to keep the NFT alive. If you don't transfer it for a period of time, it dies and it's no longer transferable, it's no longer ownable. So it's just a matter of as the manser, as the artist designing those creatures, we can choose when and if they die. And so far I decided not to kill them ever.

To build on that, if you could talk a little bit about the gestational period of the new animal and when it's born or created, whatever is the right word, Is there a concept of childhood? How does it grow?

Yeah. So animals, you're asking questions that I've been debating for so long. So animals stay up at the gestation period is one week, but this is again an arbitrary time. Just so that there is this auction mechanism that enable people to inject new genes, vote on the genes, et cetera. So arbitrarily, the incubation of a new aminal is one week. Once the aminal is born, it's immediate. There is no baby, adolescent adult, they don't age. So it's immediately ready to reproduce. Right. It doesn't need to. Which is interesting. Why? Because like in the organic life, there is a potentially a reason why you want to wait for things to be old enough to have survived in the environment to demonstrate that they are fit for the environment before they can reproduce. Because if you have something that is like sick and that has some genetic disease, you don't want it to be reproduced. And so in the case of aminas, it doesn't matter. You don't need like, they are all fit for their environment. It's just a matter of like, whether they will be liked or loved by the people and therefore whether they will collect funds to reproduce. And so you don't need to have this period of validation that you came out and you can live in this world as long as they came out, they are ready to live and to reproduce and to be fed and etc. So I didn't. Again, this is a design choice I did not implement. But again, those are like things that will evolve over time. I hope that there will be new species of aminals that perhaps have different phases of aging that are possible as long as someone injects that feature into will adopt this feature.
Hi, do you get emotionally attached to any of the creatures? and do you ever just have chats with the plantoid when you're at home, by yourself with a glass of wine?

Unfortunately, I speak with those things way more than I should. There's always the excuse of beta testing, but I think I'm actually really enjoying speaking with them. Yeah, no, I definitely speak with them, but it's also good. I think it's a good sign that you're creating something that you, you're creating a product that you use. It's a good sign, maybe a useful product. No, I have a lot of fun talking with them and designing new personalities and things like. No. So right now they only recognize the wallet, you know, so they don't recognize the voice.
Are you working on any plantoids with new features?

I'm working on the next Plantoid 16 as a new artist is going to be a portrait maker. And so that one will have a little video cam that will, when you feed it, it's going to wait for, for a human face to show up and take a snapshot and then it's going to take and make a portrait of the person and distribute it. So it's kind of like a way of creating a progressive and decentralized version of a PFP collection. But you actually have to come in front of the plantoid, feed it in order to get your own profile picture. And they might potentially include the possibility of recognizing the people that they have already encountered and that they have already fed because they have like facial recognition. But so far it's like very, very blockchain based. So they only look at the interaction on the blockchain. So if you, if you feed them and you have already fed them, then the aminal will love you more. But you know, and Plantize right now is very neutral. It's just like feed me. And the more you feed me, the longer, the more processing power I'm going to use for making the poem. But I have to say it's very strange, but this one, Plantoid 14, I don't know why, I think I have a little bit of a crush. It's very strange because the others I don't. But Plantoid 14 is like I'm a little bit of a crush, so maybe we can watch the outcome.
Can you explain the technical process of getting the NFT?

So the way it works just for like technical understanding. So when you feed it, you immediately get an nft. But it's an NFT that is empty because it has not done all the processing. And so you have like an unrevealed nft. And then after the processing is done is updating and then you can. But you still have to click. So you still have to make a transaction and then you can reveal it. And so those are NFTs that have a one time ability to update their metadata in order to integrate the resulting video. And then we can see what, what you would have had if you had fed it.

I have a question maybe about the work in a more traditional art world context. I wonder. Of course, to be. The work wants to be fed, to sort of keep the progeny and whatever.
